question: My God, it's hot. I stepped out of the shower and stared sweating again. ... It's still burning? Jesus, it's bigger! And I thought you were making me hear those sirens. What is it?
answer: The Seawater Inn. My family used to eat dinner there twenty-five years ago. Now somebody's torched it to clear the lot.

question: That's a shame.
answer: Probably one of my clients.

question: I'm leaving.
answer: It's four a.m.

question: I go on duty at Miami Airport at seven. I wouldn't mind having breakfast... What do you care? You're watching the fire. You're done with me. I'm just getting into my uniform here... You've had your fun. You're spent. I'll just slip into my uniform here and slip away.
answer: My history's burning up out here.

question: Hey, I don't mind. I'm leaving. Why do they make these damn skirts so hard to zip...
answer: Where's your hat?

question: Hey... hey... ... don't wrinkle it!
answer: 'You're spent.' Where'd you hear that?

question: 'You're spent.' Where'd you hear that?
answer: Mr. Racine, I do no longer care whether these alleged toilets were ever actually en route from Indiana or not. I think we're wasting our time here. It's pretty clear your client has attempted to defraud the county in a not very ingenious manner. The Assistant Prosecutor has made what I consider a generous offer. And given that you've failed to generate even the semblance of a defense --

question: Judge Costanza, perhaps when I've presented all --
answer: Yeah, yeah. If I were you, I'd recommend to your client that held quickly do as Mr. Lowenstein here has suggested -- plead nolo contendre, file Chapter Eleven and agree never to do business with Okeelanta County again.

question: You would look favorably on that?
answer: He can walk. But don't test my patience for even five more minutes. If he hesitates, I'll nail him.

question: I'll talk to him.
answer: Mr. Racine. Next time you come into my courtroom I hope you've got either a better defense or a better class of client.

question: Thank you, Your Honor.
answer: -- I think I've underestimated you, Ned. I don't know why it took me so long. You've started using your incompetence as a weapon.

question: My defense was evolving. You guys got scared. Costanza doesn't like me. What'd I do to him?
answer: He's an unhappy man, Thinks he should be Circuit Court by now. Here he is in a state with really top-notch corruption and he's stuck with the county toilets. I'm surprised you weren't in on that toilet caper. Could have been that quick score you've always been searching for.

question: What's the word from the hallowed halls of justice? Anything juicy?
answer: Maybe Stella was in on it. Stella, when you gonna get a real air conditioner in here.

question: You don't like it there's lots of other places.
answer: They don't have you. Gotta go. You can't buy me. No sirree, I don't come cheap.

question: Why does he do that?
answer: He's pretty good, that's the weird part.

question: Did you hear about Dr. Block?
answer: No. Do I want to?

question: Agnes Marshall.
answer: That must have been Mrs. Block's idea, some kind of punishment.

question: It was! How'd you know? Christ, you're plugged in better than me. So you must know about Mrs. Block's friend in Ocean Grove.
answer: Stella, this is beneath even you. Things must be slow.

question: Mrs. Singer, I would have gladly come to the house. Don't worry about it. I'll find you a doctor who's more understanding. Is it bad today? How well I know. We'll sue those reckless bastards dry. Excuse my language. You can stand here with me if you want, but you'll have to agree not to talk about the heat.
answer: I'm a married woman.

question: Meaning what?
answer: Meaning I'm not looking for company.

question: Then you should have said -- 'I'm a happily married woman.'
answer: That's my business.

question: What?
answer: How happy I am.

question: And how, happy is that?
answer: You're not too smart, are you? I like that in a man.

question: What else you like -- Ugly? Lazy? Horny? I got 'em all.
answer: You don't look lazy. Tell me, does chat like that work with most women?

question: Some. If they haven't been around much.
answer: I wondered. Thought maybe I was out of touch.

question: How 'bout I buy you a drink?
answer: I told you. I've got a husband.

question: I'll buy him one too.
answer: He's out of town.

question: My favorite kind. We'll drink to him.
answer: He only comes up on the weekends.

question: I'm liking him better all the time. You better take me up on this quick. In another forty-five minutes I'm going to give up and walk away.
answer: You want to buy me something? I'll take one of these.

question: What kind?
answer: Cherry.

question: Make it two. You're not staying in Miranda Beach. I would have noticed you.
answer: Is this town that small?

question: Pinehaven. You're staying up in Pinehaven, on the waterway. You have a house.
answer: How'd you know?

question: You look like Pinehaven.
answer: How does Pinehaven look?

question: Well tended.
answer: Yes, I'm well tended, all right. Well tended. What about you?

question: Me? I need tending. I need someone to take care of me. Rub my tired muscles. Smooth out my sheets.
answer: Get married.

question: I just need it for tonight.
answer: Good. Nice move, Matty.

question: Matty. I like it. Right over your heart.
answer: At least it's cool. I'm burning up.

question: I asked you not to talk about the heat.
answer: Would you get me a paper towel or something? Dip it in some cold water.

question: Right away. I'll even wipe it off for you.
answer: You don't want to lick it?

question: Look who's here. Isn't this a coincidence?
answer: I know you.

question: You're the one that doesn't want to talk about the heat. Too bad. I'd tell you about my chimes.
answer: What about them?

question: The wind chimes on my porch. They keep ringing and I go out there expecting a cool breeze. That's what they've always meant. But not this summer, This summer it's just hot air.
answer: Do I remind you of hot air? Bourbon, any kind, on the rocks. Another?

question: What are you doing in Pinehaven?
answer: I'm no yokel. Why, I was all the way to Miami once.

question: There are some men, once they get a whiff of it, they'll trail you like a hound.
answer: I'm not that eager.

question: What is your name, anyway?
answer: Ned Racine.

question: Matty Walker.
answer: Are you all right?

question: Yes. My temperature runs a couple degrees high. Around 100 all the time I don't mind it. It's the engine or something.
answer: Maybe you need a tune-up.

question: Don't tell me -- you have just the right tool.
answer: I don't talk that way.

question: How'd you find me, Ned?
answer: This is the only joint in Pinehaven.

question: How'd you know I drink?
answer: You seemed like a woman with all the vices.

question: You shouldn't have come. You're going to be disappointed.
answer: What'd I do?

question: A lot of them have tried that seat. You're the first one I've let stay.
answer: You must come here a lot.

question: Most men are little boys.
answer: Maybe you should drink at home.

question: Too quiet.
answer: Maybe you shouldn't dress like that.

question: This is a blouse and a skirt. I don't know what you're talking about.
answer: You shouldn't wear that body.

question: I don't like my body much. It's never been right. Sometimes, I don't know. I get so sick of everything, I'm not sure I care anymore. Do you know what I mean, Ned?
answer: I know that sometimes the shit comes down SO heavy I feel like I should wear a hat.

question: Yeah, that's what I mean. I think I'll get out of here now. I'm going home.
answer: I'll take you.

question: I have a car.
answer: I'll follow you. I want to see the chimes.

question: You want to see the chimes.
answer: I want to hear them.

question: That's all. If I let you, that's all.
answer: I'm not looking for trouble.

question: I mean it. I like you. But my life is complicated enough. This is my community bar. I might have to come here with my husband some time. Would you leave before me? Wait in your car? I know it seems silly...
answer: I don't know who we're going to fool. You've been pretty friendly.

question: Now leave me alone.
answer: Lady, you must be some kind of crazy! Jesus.

question: Remember your promise.
answer: Just like my place. No help?

question: She goes home nights.
answer: You're not nervous alone?

question: No.
answer: You do have chimes. What's that?

question: A gazebo
answer: No, out there.

question: Boat house.
answer: What is in there?

question: Boat. It's a mess. There's a row boat, a lot of lounge chairs... things like that. I think you should go now.
answer: I just got here.

question: You've seen them. Please go.
answer: You didn't bring me here to see your wind chimes.

question: Yes, I did. I said what I meant. Do you ever do that?
answer: No. not very often. I don't think you want me to go.

question: Yes... Please.
answer: There's nothing to be afraid of.

question: There is for me. Thank you. I'm sorry, I shouldn't have lot you come.
answer: You're not so tough after all, are you?

question: No... I'm weak. Yes, yes...
answer: That's right... that's right.

question: I didn't want this to happen. But I didn't try hard enough to stop it... Because I wanted you. I wanted you here, like this ... This is bad for me. I know it. Now nothing's going to be the same anymore.
answer: I like this place. It's got a nice feel.

question: You were on top.
answer: So it could use a better mattress. See to it, will you?

question: Yes sir.
answer: Hey, gimme a break here. It takes a little while.

question: It's your fault.
answer: It takes me a good thirty seconds.

question: Are you sure? I just want to make sure here.
answer: Jesus, I think you're right -- -- you better be on the bottom.

question: No, you misunderstood -- -- this is my new saddle, and I just want to --
answer: Wow! No, I must object --

question: Wow! No, I must object --
answer: Racine's face; he is still rolling, but he is alone. He has just rolled off the bed. He lies there like a dead man.

question: Enough.
answer: Matty, wrapped in a thin white terrycloth robe, is stripping the bed of its sheets. Racine watches from across the room.

question: What are you doing?
answer: I've got to wash these.

question: You're afraid of your maid?
answer: That's right. My mother told me "knowledge is power."

question: This is an interesting interpretation. Is that why you've started smoking my brand?
answer: No one must know. Promise me, Ned. No one.

question: Hey, lady, wanna make love?
answer: I don't know. Maybe This sure is a friendly town.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: You are? You mean the offers no good?

question: I feel like a jerk.
answer: Maybe you were supposed to deliver it next door? You must be looking for the lady of the house.

question: I didn't see her car. I'm sorry. I got to be more careful.
answer: Mary Ann's an old friend. She's like a sister to me. She wants me to be happy.

question: You know, this has never been one of my pleasures. Car. I considered the time I spent making it -- -- like this ... penance for some sin.
answer: What sin?

question: I never knew. Maybe worshipping women instead of God. But it never did anything for me.
answer: Not even a Mercedes? With genuine calf skin upholstery?

question: No.
answer: Not this?

question: Just do what I say! Go into the living room.
answer: Come on! It's been three days. I want to see you --

question: I'm going to make it up to you tonight. But you must behave. Now go!
answer: I'm going. I'm going. I'm here.

question: Good. Good evening, sir... welcome to... to Flight 413 ... nonstop to ...
answer: What do you take me for?

question: Don't you like it?
answer: You think I'm a kid?

question: You don't like it? I thought you went for this stuff. Wait ... wait ... I want to tell you about the thing... the thing that will drop from the ceiling... in case the cabin suddenly depressurizes -- oho... What are we doing here?
answer: Listen! I love that sound.

question: I want to be in bed.
answer: Is that all you ever think about? Hey! I'm kidding.

question: You look terrible. Don't you sleep?
answer: I had a dream last night that was so boring it woke me up. I was afraid to go back to sleep. Where the hell have you been?

question: What do you mean, I been around.
answer: I've barely seen you for a month. Wait a minute -- it's some new quiff, isn't it? What's wrong with me. You've never been shy about that stuff.

question: Whatcha got in pie today, Stella?
answer: Cherry, cherry... and cherry.

question: What do you recommend?
answer: I like the cherry.

question: Hi, Glenda.
answer: Don't say it, if you don't mean it. Please, Ned, don't.

question: I do. I want you with me.
answer: I'm going to tell Edmund I want a divorce. I won't stay any longer. I would have, if you hadn't come along. The life is comfortable. I was willing to go on. But you've reminded me of what it can be... I know now that these last three years I've been living half a life. It's my fault, I don't deny it. You have to let yourself be bought. I did. I let it happen. I've lived so much of my life with nothing. When you have no money, you have no choices. I don't care what they say -- money is freedom. That's something they don't teach you in school. But I found out. And when Edmund came along when I saw a chance to stop struggling I took it. I'm not ashamed. He got what he wanted... he has a knack for that. But no more. I'm ready to walk away from the money. I have to be with you.

question: It is conceivable I'll make a buck someday.
answer: Oh, I know you will, darling. I didn't mean that. I know you will. But it doesn't matter. It's you I want. That's all.

question: Anyway, you'll come out all right.
answer: Of the divorce?

question: Yeah. He's ripe.
answer: No. I signed a pre-nuptial agreement.

question: What?
answer: He insisted. He blamed it on his sister Roz -- she's always hated me -- but I know he wanted it too.

question: How is it?
answer: Bad. I get some money for a year. Not much. That's it. But I don't care, Ned. Not if I can be with you. Does it matter, Ned? Tell me the truth please. I'll understand, I swear to you.

question: The truth? I wish you were going to be loaded. Does it matter? No. No.
answer: God, you've made me happy. It's time for your present. From now on, when it starts coming down on you, I'll be there to protect you. Put it on! I'll bet I guessed the size right. I love it.

question: I want to see.
answer: Look in my eyes. Can you see yourself? Here!

question: Big weekend planned?
answer: Nope, Small weekend. Tiny little weekend.

question: There's jazz tonight at the beach... if you're not doing anything...
answer: Beverly, do yourself a big favor and forget it.

question: Forget what?
answer: Whatever you're thinking. Yeah.

question: Whatever you're thinking. Yeah.
answer: Come to me.

question: Did you tell him?
answer: No... I couldn't.

question: Okay, I'm coming. How do you know?
answer: I saw the will once. He showed it to me. He was trying to prove something ... how much he loved me or something.

question: How'd he get so fat?
answer: The stock market, investments, real estate. He doesn't tell me anything, but I've picked up a little. I know they own a lot of land along the shore here.

question: Who's "they"'
answer: He's never introduced me to anyone. I'm not sure if they're all legitimate.

question: I wonder what they call themselves. Maybe I've heard of them.
answer: They own that old place in Miranda Beach, The Breakers... I know that.

question: The Breakers? I thought Hermie Fisher owned that land.
answer: Edmund mentioned it once. Ned, it scares me to talk about these things.

question: Why?
answer: You know.

question: No. I don't.
answer: Let's just not, okay? Let's not think about all he's got.

question: What is it, Matty? Tell me exactly what frightens you.
answer: I'm afraid... because when I think about it, I wish that he'd die. That's really what I want. It's horrible and ugly and It's what I most want.

question: That's where we're at, isn't it, Matty?
answer: What do you mean?

question: That's what we're both thinking -- how good it'd be for us if he were gone. It'd be real sweet for us.
answer: Don't talk about it, Ned. Please don't. Talk is dangerous. Sometimes it makes things happen, it makes it real.

question: Don't let it scare you. Because he's not gonna die. There's nothing wrong with him, is there? There's no reason to think he's gonna die, is there? That's right. So we might as well forget about it, It's not gonna just happen to make things nice for us... It won't just happen.
answer: I'm afraid, Ned.

question: Maybe that's a smart way to be now, Matty. Maybe we both should be. The only thing wrong with your husband right now... is us. Well, well. Hello to you --
answer: Hello. Darling, I'd like you to meet Mr. Racine. I'm sorry. I don't know your first name.

question: Right.
answer: That hasn't changed, has it?

question: No, we're very happy with it.
answer: I can understand that. It's a terrific place.

question: Are you going in?
answer: I was just going to grab a bite.

question: Join us.
answer: No. Thanks very much, but I don't want to interfere with --

question: Don't be silly. Come on. We have room for three, don't we? I've heard this place is great. But you can't get near it on the weekends and I don't get down during the week much.
answer: Is that right?

question: I was a lawyer. Still am, I guess. But I don't practice. Went to Columbia. You? Good school. I got bored with it quick. I guess I didn't have the temperament. I wanted to make the money faster. Is there a living in it here?
answer: I can afford to send my shirts out. And eat here once a month, if I don't order an appetizer.

question: That's all right. I don't like it much.
answer: What's to like. That's the way of the world. Most people despise their jobs.

question: Do you?
answer: No. I love it. But it's not a job.

question: What is it, exactly?
answer: Various things. This and that. Here and there.

question: You don't have to be specific.
answer: Finance, basically. Venture capital, Investments, real estate. We're into a few things.

question: Yeah? Around here?
answer: Some. We own some things here.

question: She's something, isn't she?
answer: A lovely lady.

question: Yes, she is. I'm crazy about her. If I ever thought she was seeing another guy... I don't know. I'd understand how it could happen. Her being the way she is. I'd understand it. But I think I'd kill the guy with my bare hands.
answer: That's understanding.

question: You wouldn't believe the dorkus she was with when I met her. The guy came to us with a business proposition. We're always looking for opportunities. If the conditions are right. We're willing to take an occasional risk, if the downside isn't too steep. But this guy hadn't done his homework, he didn't know the bottom line. That's how I knew he was full of shit. You've got to know the bottom line. That's all that really counts. He didn't have the goods, this guy. He was like a lot of guys you run into -- they want to get rich, they want to do it quick, they want to be there with one score. But they're not willing to do what's necessary. Do you know what I mean?
answer: I'm not sure. You mean, lay the groundwork? Earn it?

question: No. I mean do what's necessary. Whatever's necessary.
answer: Yeah. I know that kind of guy. I can't stand that. It makes me sick.

question: Me too.
answer: I'm not like that.

question: Jesus! Did Beverly see you?
answer: I waited till I saw her leave. Please don't be angry with me.

question: Angry? I'm not angry -- How'd you get in?
answer: It didn't lock. Oh. Ned, hold me. Please just hold me, God, I love you. He left this morning. I had to see you.

question: I know.
answer: I couldn't call. I'm afraid to call. I was afraid you wouldn't let me come.

question: Yes, that's right. You can't call. Never call. We have to be very careful now about the phone. The phone company keeps records.
answer: I'm careful. I hated it, Ned. I hated sitting there with the two of you. I thought I was going to scream.

question: You did good. You've called my apartment from the house.
answer: No, never.

question: No? Those two times --
answer: I went to phone booths. I'm afraid of him, Ned. I'm always afraid.

question: That's good. We have to be careful about the phones now.
answer: Why, Ned, why do you say this now?

question: We could account for a couple calls. We've had some contact. That would make sense.
answer: Why, Ned? What's happened?

question: Because we're going to kill him. We both know that. That's what you want, isn't it? We knew it was coming. It's the only way we can get everything we want, isn't it? The man's gonna die for no reason but we want him dead. He doesn't deserve it. Let's not ever say that. We're doing it for us. And you're going to inherit half of everything he owns. That's what the will says, right? That's it then. We're gonna kill him. And I think I know how.
answer: It's real, then?

question: Yeah, it's real all right, and if we're not careful, it's gonna be the last real thing we do. I know where he is. It's not far from here. I don't want you with me.
answer: I thought we settled that. I'll wait in the car, but -- -- I want to take the risks with you. We're both doing this.

question: Whatsa matter, you can't think with a little music? Like this, I said.
answer: That's it?

question: It's fast. It's hot. It's simple. You can use the clock or rig it to something that moves. It starts big and it'll go with just the mag clips. If you want more, splash a little accelerator around.
answer: Just regular gasoline?

question: Regular, unleaded, supreme -- whatever you like, counselor. I got to tell you, though, this mama has a big drawback.
answer: What?

question: It's easy to spot, even after the meltdown. They'll know it's arson.
answer: I don't care about that. That's all there is to it?

question: No. No-no-no-no. That ain't all there is to it. You gotta get in, you gotta get out. You gotta pick the right spot and the right time. And you gotta try not to get famous while you're in the act. If that was all there was to it, any idiot could do it.
answer: Sorry.

question: Hey, now I want to ask you something, Are you listening, asshole, because I like you? I got a serious question for you. What the fuck are you doing? This is not shit for you to be messing with. Are you ready to hear something? See if this sounds familiar. Anytime you try a decent crime, there is fifty ways to fuck up. If you think of twenty-five of them you're a genius. And you're no genius. You know who told me that? Listen, man, maybe you should let me do it for you. Gratis. I'll do it. I wouldn't even be on the street if it weren't for you.
answer: Thanks.

question: I don't know why he's so crazy about her. Maybe because he never had any of his own. She's a cute little girl, all right, but other than that... I know this, though, her mother has worked plenty hard to keep Heather on Edmund's mind, Always bringing her around, reporting everything she does in school. That Roz is a smart one. And you know that anything Heather inherits goes straight to Roz. Heather won't even get a look at it. That's the part I can't stand. That's why it seems so wrong to have half of it go to her.
answer: That's the way it is. There's nothing we can do about it.

question: Are you sure, Ned? I've been thinking about it. Maybe there is. The will is with his lawyer in Miami I know that. What if I could get him to bring it home? He did it once, he'd do it again. If I could swing it, couldn't we rewrite it? Change it. Then when he dies, I could find the new one. We could just change it a little. Every little change would mean a lot to us, End. You're a lawyer. You know how to write it. It wouldn't seem so odd. I could say he brought it home and we talked about it and decided to make some changes up here. And I knew you already --
answer: No. Forget it.

question: I just don't see why Heather should take half --
answer: Listen to me, Matty. Nothing strange can happen in his life right now, not one thing out of the ordinary. That's vital, that's the main thing. If anything does, the chances double that we get caught. You and I are walking out there on the edge every second now. One false move and we're gonna fall off. It'll be all over. You've got to remember that all the time. You'll get half of everything and it'll be plenty. No matter what it is, we're gonna be satisfied. We're not gonna get greedy. If we do, we'll get burned. You gotta believe me, baby, the odds that we'll get burned are good enough without looking for trouble.

question: You're right, darling. I'm sorry. I know you're right.
answer: Okay. Gotta go.

question: Be careful.
answer: I'm just going for a ride. I wish it was all this dangerous.

question: I love you.
answer: And?

question: The side door.
answer: And?

question: Two A.M. I send him down.
answer: We won't talk again after I leave here tonight. I'll be in Miami by noon Friday. You won't be able to reach me. When I see you again, he'll be dead.

question: You trying to kill me? I'm going downstairs. Do you want anything?
answer: I'll go down with you.

question: Christ, woman, did you ever hear of turning on the lights?
answer: Edmund... wait!

question: What is it?
answer: Put on a robe or something. What if Heather wakes up and comes down.

question: Damn. She's not going to wake up at 2 o'clock in the morning... You don't really mind, do you? Roz will pick her up on Friday. And don't worry, Roz won't stay overnight.
answer: She can do whatever she wants.

question: Listen, I don't know if I'll be able to come up next weekend. I'll know more later. I'll call you.
answer: My God, you scared me. You shouldn't be here. Heather's still here. She's upstairs.

question: My God, you scared me. You shouldn't be here. Heather's still here. She's upstairs.
answer: -- Asleep.

question: I miss you so badly. But it's too dangerous.
answer: She won't wake up now.

question: You're all wet.
answer: I've been out there waiting for two hours.

question: Any time, Roz. She's a pleasure.
answer: Yeah?

question: It is me.
answer: It's open.

question: Why haven't you answered your phone?
answer: You took a chance coming here. Where's Edmund?

question: He's not coming up this weekend. Why haven't you answered?
answer: I didn't want to talk. I just wanted to think.

question: Can I get in with you? I don't know what Heather will tell Roz. Maybe nothing. Maybe she'll be embarrassed or afraid. Maybe she'll think she imagined the whole thing.
answer: Maybe we all did.

question: We'll know if she does tell. Roz will report to Edmund quick enough. It's exactly what she's always wanted. I've been thinking, too.
answer: And what have you got?

question: I think we should give it up. We haven't done anything criminal, yet.
answer: It's not too late to back out.

question: That's right. I don't think we can do it.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Things have already started to go wrong. I feel like we got to the edge and looked over and, well, it was too much. We'll just have to live with that. I'll divorce him. And we won't have his money. Part of me wants it so bad. I'd be lying if I said I didn't. But it's the worst part of me, the weakest part. All that matters is that we're together.
answer: You don't think I can pull it off.

question: It's not you, it's us. I'm sure I'll make some mistake.
answer: That's not what you really mean, is it, Matty?

question: Yes it is.
answer: No, it isn't. You think he's too much for me. You think I'll fuck it up, get us caught.

question: No, darling. Don't talk that way. It's not true.
answer: No? Well that's what I've been thinking.

question: You're wrong. Don't think that, ever! I know you could do it. But all I care about is you. The money doesn't matter.
answer: It does in this world, the one we're living in.

question: Why torture ourselves about it?
answer: When's he coming back?

question: Friday.
answer: That'll be it, then. Nothing will stop us.

question: Is that what you really want? Are you sure?
answer: Yeah. I wasn't before, but I am now. This time you're going to know how to reach me. I don't want any more surprises.

question: What's wrong?
answer: I think there's someone downstairs I heard something.

question: Are you sure? Should I call the police?
answer: Will you be quiet? I'm going to nail the bastard.

question: Edmund, what's that?
answer: Will you be quiet?

question: I've never seen that.
answer: I've got a surprise for this fucker.

question: Edmund, be careful! He has a gun!
answer: Where?

question: Hello. Yes.
answer: Mr. Racine.

question: Yes.
answer: This is Miles Hardin of Morris and Dale in Miami.

question: Yes.
answer: As you know, we represented Edmund Walker.

question: Yes.
answer: Yes, well, Mrs. Walker has submitted the new will you wrote up there.

question: Yes... I see.
answer: And frankly, Mr. Racine, I think we may have a problem.

question: Uh-huh. What problem is that?
answer: Well, I'd rather discuss it in person. In fact I think it might be best if we could all get together down there. That is, if you wouldn't object.

question: No no, that would be all right.
answer: Good. We have a relationship with a firm in West Palm -- Shiller, Hastings.

question: I know of them.
answer: I've arranged to have the use of their offices. I thought we might try to make it tomorrow, say ten o'clock. Would that be possible for you?

question: Yes, I think so.
answer: Good. Mrs. Walker told me she would be back down there by then. And I've asked Mrs. Kraft, Mr. Walker's sister, to join us, also. I'll see you then.

question: Right.
answer: Good-bye.

question: Okay. Try again later.
answer: Miles Hardin, Mr. Racine.

question: How are you?
answer: I don't think you know Mrs. Kraft.

question: Yes, what does all this mean?
answer: It means, I'm afraid, that Edmund's will is invalid. Edmund Walker died interstate, as though there were no will at all.

question: So... what happens now?
answer: You don't know?

question: No, I don't.
answer: Perhaps Mr. Racine would like to tell you.

question: My god. You mean... it's all mine?
answer: Though that was clearly not your husband's intention.

question: My god.
answer: He intended Heather to benefit --

question: Of course, of course, I understand. Of course.
answer: As you can imagine, Mrs. Walkers given the circumstances of Edmund's death, none of this is going to happen... how should I say it... simply.

question: ... Of course...
answer: You look good in black.

question: I've missed you so badly. I need you.
answer: At first I couldn't figure out when you got ahold of my stationery and stuff. It finally came to me... Edmund's signature must have been a snap. And you knew I wasn't gonna challenge mine --

question: Please stop. I don't blame you for hating me right now.
answer: You've really done it, Matty. You really have.

question: Will you come to the house tonight? I want you more right now than I ever have. I know how you must feel about me. But please come tonight.
answer: I hope you haven't done us in. Hi, guys. Just come on in, make yourself at home.

question: I've gotta bring my wife up here. She thinks our house is the hottest place in the county.
answer: It ain't great this time of day.

question: Ned, how did you get involved with this Matty Walker?
answer: What do you mean?

question: I mean she's poison, man. Tell me what you know about her old man's death.
answer: What read in the paper. He died in the fire. Looks like arson--

question: That's right. A very rough group of fellows, too. They're arguing with the insurance company right now. It's possible they wanted to cut old Edmund out. I'm sure they're not too broken up over his departure. But this just doesn't seem like a neat way to handle something like that.
answer: It's not their style. They're very smooth. They'd rather destroy you than kill you. And they hate publicity.

question: Course guys like that make a lot of enemies. Coulda been a grudge match from the outside, I suppose. But me, I'm kinda interested in the grieving widow.
answer: Her sister-in-law's got plenty of ideas along that line, too. She could barely contain herself today, I could tell. But she wants to wait and see how Matty treats her on the estate. She doesn't want to blow it.

question: How'd you get involved?
answer: They asked me to re-do the will. I met with her and Edmund. It was pretty simple. This Mary Ann Simpson witnessed it with me. Walker didn't seem to think it was any big deal.

question: That's it?
answer: That's it.

question: What was this Simpson's story?
answer: I don't know... old friend of theirs, good-looking broad. She was just passing through.

question: On her way to Europe? The passport people can't find any record of that. What do you think? About the wife?
answer: I suppose it's possible. I don't know much about her, except -- -- what I've seen. Wouldn't shock me, either way.

question: ... Mary Ann and I left Wheaton together and went to Chicago. We didn't know what we were doing. I got in bad trouble with drugs. Speed. Really bad. I did things... Whatever's the evilest thing you can think of me now, I did worse things then. There's nothing lower than the animal I was then. Worse than you can imagine. I thought I would die. I prayed I would... And then a man helped me. He got me clean. He didn't want much in return, either... He was a lawyer and he put me to work in his office. I learned a lot there. One time I even thought I might go to law school. ... That's where I picked up the business about making a will invalid. That happened to him once. I swear I would never have used that if I'd known about your case... I was afraid to tell you, Ned. I knew you wouldn't let me do it. I'm greedy, like you said. I wanted us to have it all. I don't blame you for thinking I'm bad. I am. I know it. I'd understand if you just cut me off now. If you never trusted me again. You'd probably be smart. But you must believe one thing. I love you. I love you and need you. I want to be with you forever.
answer: They already think you're involved.

question: I don't care.
answer: Great.

question: There's nothing we can do about it now. In a little while we'll either have the money or we won't. It's out of our hands. I fired the housekeeper. We can stay together as long as we want. We're all alone here now.
answer: That's right. I've been down there a lot lately. Isn't that amazing? Miami. Jesus. I'm handling the purchase of some property down there. I'll be going back in the future... if that's all right, if it's still legal to go to Miami.

question: I'll go out this way. I've had a lot of experience with disgruntled people. I'll be over to Stella's, if you want to have some lunch. Hello, Mrs. Kraft.
answer: Hello, Mr. Racine.

question: How are you making out?
answer: We're all right, I guess.

question: You must be Heather. I'm Ned Racine, Heather. I've heard a lot about you. It's nice to meet you.
answer: Thank you.

question: I'm sorry our town is so hot for your visit.
answer: It sure is.

question: Hi, Racine. How you doing today?
answer: I'm fine, Stella. I'm fine. What's the latest? Any hot news?

question: Nothing much doing. What'll it be?
answer: What's the special?

question: Veal outlets.
answer: What day'd you cook 'em?

question: Are you ready to hear something wild?
answer: I don't know. I may have had my share for the day.

question: No, this is right up your alley. Little Heather comes out onto the back porch, and this dude is out there with her aunt, see? And he's turned away with his pants or shorts or whatever dropped, so he's mooning the little girl, right. And he and your friend are going at something which Heather couldn't quite figure out. Poor little Heather! She's never seen one angry before. But it made quite an impression on her. Yessirree! That's all she can remember.
answer: That's it?

question: One other thing. She says the guy's hair was greasy. He wore it slicked back. "Like a Cuban," she says. I loved that! Can you imagine poor Heather? She hustled back to bed after getting a gander at that. And listen to why she got up in the first place, this is the capper. She had a nightmare! Christ, can you imagine what kinds of dreams she had the rest of the night?
answer: Don't say that. Don't say you don't have them.

question: Don't say that. Don't say you don't have them.
answer: I swear to you, I don't. What's wrong with you?

question: They had to be here when you cleaned up that night. Think about it, think hard. They've probably got my prints on them.
answer: I must have missed them. I wasn't looking for them. I thought they were on Edmund.

question: So where could they have gone?
answer: I don't know. Betty!

question: The housekeeper? Where would she have put them? You've been through his things.
answer: She might have taken them. Listen to me. That's why I fired her. After Edmund's death she started acting strange. She was always watching me, listening to my calls.

question: That's crazy. You imagined it. I know, I've been imagining things, too. Plenty.
answer: No, Ned, not with her I wasn't. I could tell there was a difference. Maybe she know about us. Maybe she wants something.

question: Don't you think we would have heard from her by now?
answer: I don't know what to think. I'm worried. But it's not about the glasses. Or your friends. It's us.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Your first reaction is to accuse me. What's happening to you? I don't know if we can hold on like this. Hardin called today. He said everything should be cleared up by next week. I'll get the money He apologized for the delay.

question: They've been stalling. They're draggin it out, hoping they'd come up with some way to implicate you.
answer: But they haven't been able to. Soon it'll be all ours. That's why we've got to hold together, Ned. It won't be long, then we'll get away from here. Out from under all this. All we have is each other. I'd kill myself if I thought this thing would destroy us. I couldn't take it.

question: Peter?
answer: Hi, Ned.

question: What are you doing here?
answer: I've been looking for you.

question: Yeah?
answer: Yeah. You always run this late?

question: Nah. I'm going to Miami tomorrow. I'm not gonna have time.
answer: What's in Miami?

question: I'm closing this real estate deal I've been working on.
answer: You're some kind of health nut. Matty Walker smokes that same brand. I noticed that.

question: Is this gonna be one of those conversations? Maybe I should have my lawyer present.
answer: Buddy, your lawyer is present. You know, that Edmund Walker was a bad guy. The more I find out about him, the happier I am he's dead. I figure it's a positive thing for the world.

question: You're not known for being a hardliner.
answer: Mmm. I have my own standards. I try to keep them private. As far as I'm concerned, I don't care who killed him. And I don't care who gets rich because of it. But Oscar, Oscar's not like that. His whole life is based on doing the right thing. He's the only person I know like that. Sometimes it's a real pain in the ass. Even for him. Oscar's unhappy right now. He's in pain.

question: Why is that?
answer: Because he likes you. He likes you even better than I do. That's why he's been busting his butt trying to locate this Mary Ann Simpson. They finally found her place in Miami yesterday, but the woman herself was gone... looked like she left in a hurry. Oscar thought any story she could tell might help you. He thinks you need help. Someone's putting you in deep trouble, my friend. From about three thirty to five AM on the night Walker was killed, someone called your hotel room repeatedly. The hotel didn't want to put them through, but whoever was calling convinced them it was an emergency. The phone rang and rang, but you didn't answer. Don't say anything. Save it for some Other time. It gets worse. Now someone's trying to give us Edmund's glasses. We don't know who. We don't know what the glasses will tell us. But our negotiations are continuing. I wish I knew what to tell you, Ned. But I don't have any good ideas. I'll see ya.

question: We know each other, don't we? I'm Michael Glenn. With Bashford, Hillerman.
answer: Ned Racine.

question: Christ, I've done it again. I'm just meeting some people. Hey, this is silly. You're not still mad about that Gourson business? We had to do it. Costanza practically insisted we sue you. Listen, nobody at our place likes malpractice against other lawyers.
answer: Forget it.

question: I tried to make it up to you. Did you ever meet a lady named Matty Walker? You'd remember her. A very hot number.
answer: Matty Walker?

question: Yeah. I met her at a party. She said she was going up there and she wanted to know about lawyers. I gave her your name.
answer: When was this?

question: I don't know... long time. Maybe September. Oops, gotta go.
answer: Did you tell her about the Gourson case?

question: Hey, I was trying to get you work.
answer: Did you tell her about Gourson?

question: I don't know. It's a thing in Lauderdale. Something must've gone wrong, but they're not telling me. I'm a little worried.
answer: I'll find out.

question: No, no. That's not why I called you. In fact, I got me another lawyer. I think it would be better. You know Schlisgal.
answer: He's good.

question: This broad came to me last week. A real looker. She said you told her how to reach me, I figured you musta, she knew all about it. She said you wanted another one. Yeah, I was afraid of that. But I'm a slow thinker. She had me show her how to rig it to a door, with a little delay. Does any of this mean anything to you? Then I'm glad I told you. Watch your step.
answer: Thanks, Teddy.

question: Yeah. Hello.
answer: Hello, Ned. Can we talk?

question: Okay. Where are you?
answer: I'm in Miami. I've been running around like crazy and I could reach you before I left.

question: Tell me.
answer: I've got the money. I've taken it and sent it somewhere safe. It's all ours now. But that's not the best part.

question: What's the best part?
answer: The glasses. I got them back. That is, they should be ours by now. Betty had them. She wanted money. That's why I had to come down here. She made it all very difficult, but I think it worked out.

question: Do you have them?
answer: No. She wouldn't do that. She's putting them in the boathouse. In the top drawer of the dresser in the boathouse. They should be there now, if she's kept up her end.

question: Yes.
answer: I think you'd better get them right away. I don't trust her.

question: In the boathouse.
answer: That's right. The top drawer of the dresser. Oh. Ned, we're going to be all right. I'll leave here as soon as I can. I should be there by seven- thirty. I can't wait to see you, darling. We've made it. Are you all right?

question: Yes.
answer: Good-bye, sweetheart.

question: Hello, darling.
answer: Hello, Matty.

question: Where's your car?
answer: In the back. With yours.

question: Why haven't you turned on the lights?
answer: I could see.

question: It's all ours now, Ned. We could leave tonight if we wanted. It's over.
answer: Yes, it is.

question: What's this --?
answer: It's Edmund's gun. You remember it, don't you?

question: What is it, Ned? What's happened?
answer: I think you know.

question: No. I swear to you, I don't!
answer: It's the glasses, Matty.

question: Weren't they there? Didn't she bring them?
answer: I didn't see them.

question: She promised she'd bring them.
answer: Maybe I missed them. The way you missed them that night.

question: Ned, I don't know what you think, but you're wrong. I haven't done anything to hurt you. I love you. You've got to believe me.
answer: Keep talking, Matty. Experience shows I can be convinced of anything.

question: I did arrange to meet you. But, Ned, it all changed. You changed it. I fell in love with you. I didn't plan that...
answer: You never quit, do you? You just keep on coming.

question: How can I prove it to you? What can I say?
answer: The glasses, Matty. Why don't you go down there and get them?

question: But you said they weren't there.
answer: I said I didn't see them.

question: I'll go, Ned. I'll go and look for them. Ned... no matter what you think, I do love you.
answer: No, Matty! Stop! Don't go in! Matty. She's alive. But what if that was someone else's body in there? What if it was already there when I got there -- dead and waiting for me. Maybe her friend... Mary Ann.

question: No, Matty! Stop! Don't go in! Matty. She's alive. But what if that was someone else's body in there? What if it was already there when I got there -- dead and waiting for me. Maybe her friend... Mary Ann.
answer: Her teeth were left, man. We sent them back to Illinois. The identification was positive. That was her, that was Matty Tyler Walker. That was her and she's dead.

question: You're not listening to me. What if she's been using this other girl's name? Since she met Walker three years ago, since she first spotted him and decided to take him... one way or another. Maybe Walker -- or any of us -- never knew her real name.
answer: Why would she want to hide her identity?

question: I don't know. Maybe there was something in her past, something so bad she was afraid it would queer it with Walker if he found out -- that he'd never marry her. Let's say she's living as the other girl, this girl from her past. Someone whose history she knew and could use any way she wanted. And there's only one person in the world who knows the truth. And then just when Matty's got me on the line, when she's finally going to collect, that one person shows up. That girl. Finds her. And threatens to expose her. So Matty starts paying her off. Maybe she even promises to cut her in on Edmunds' money. Now she's got to share it with two people. But when Matty sees a way to get rid of both of them at once. A way to solve all her problems and get clear, with no one looking for her. At the boathouse. You find two bodies, me and this girl. Two killers dead. Case closed. You can't find the money, can you, Oscar? Doesn't that tell you something?
answer: It tells me she moved it and we can't find it. And that don't mean shit. It could be sittin' in any bank in the world waiting for a dead lady to come for it. Do you hear what you're saying? It's crazy. This Matty would've had to been one quick, smart broad.

question: Oscar, don't you understand? That was her special gift she was relentless. Matty was the kind of person who could do what was necessary. Whatever was necessary.
answer: Racine, you got to face something. You killed Edmund Walker, man. And you're going down for it. Two people are dead. And no matter how you want to figure it, you ain't bringin' either of 'em back to life.
